III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention: These include, but are not limited to, the following:
(b) Denial of any essential program service as punishment.
(i) Food or creating alternative menus.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A was denied a sufficient amount of drinking water as a
punishment.
Investigation On 6/26/24 Complainant reported that Youth A had water
withheld. Complainant was at the facility with Youth A on 6/22/24
from 7:00PM to 10:30PM. During that time the air conditioning
was not working and the rooms were very warm. Complainant
stated that Youth A was given a cup of water and a honeybun for
a bedtime snack around 9:00PM.
On 6/28/24 Youth A was interviewed by MDHHS Worker. Youth A
reported she was never denied water at the facility and received
water as needed. Youth A stated she received food on a regular
basis. DCWL attempted to follow up with Youth A, however she
moved from the facility on 6/28/24. Attempts were made to contact
Youth A at her new placement on 8/12/24 and 9/3/24, without
success.
On 7/1/24 Supervisor was interviewed on-site at the facility by
Consultant 1 and MDHHS Worker. Supervisor reported Youth A
was not denied any items. Specifically, Youth A was not denied
any water. If Youth A wanted water, all she had to do was ask.
Supervisor stated Youth A had a refillable cup that she could use.
Supervisor recalled providing water to Youth A and Complainant
while they were present.
On 7/1/24 Staff 1 was interviewed on-site at the facility by
Consultant 1 and MDHHS worker. Staff 1 reported she had no
knowledge of Youth A being deprived of water while in the
conference room.
2

On 7/1/24 Staff 2 was interviewed by phone by Consultant 1 and
MDHHS worker. Staff 2 acknowledged the building had trouble
with the air conditioning. Staff 2 denied that Youth A was ever
denied water. Youth A had a refillable water bottle that she could
fill at any time.
Analysis Based on interviews with staff and youth, the facility is found to be
in compliance. Youth A and staff reported that water was not
limited or denied.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(b) Denial of any essential program service as punishment.
These include, but are not limited to, the following:
(iv) Shelter, clothing, medical care, or essential personal
needs, including culturally specific items.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A was denied toiletries as a punishment.
Investigation On 6/26/24 Complainant reported that Youth A did not have
toiletries. Complainant was at the facility with Youth A from on
6/22/24 from 7:00PM to 10:30PM. When Youth A went to take a
shower around 10:00PM, Complainant observed her bedroom did
not have any toiletries available.
Youth A moved from the facility on 6/28/24. Attempts were made
to contact Youth A at her new placement on 8/12/24 and 9/3/24,
without success.
On 7/1/24 Supervisor was interviewed on-site at the facility by
Consultant 1 and MDHHS Worker. Supervisor reported that Youth
A was not denied any hygiene products. Supervisor stated that
Youth A did not ask for any hygiene products until Complainant
came to the facility. Complainant then asked for items and they
were provided.
3

On 7/1/24 Staff 1 was interviewed on-site at the facility by
Consultant 1 and MDHHS Worker. Staff 1 stated that Youth A was
never deprived of hygiene products. If Youth A did not have a
certain item, she just needed to ask staff and it would have been
provided to her. Staff 1 clarified that Youth A was not able to keep
her hygiene items in her room as a safety measure, due to her
behaviors. Youth A washed her hair every night and was provided
hygiene items as needed.
On 7/1/24 Staff 2 was interviewed by phone by Consultant 1 and
MDHHS worker. Staff 2 reported that Youth A was never denied
any hygiene products. Youth A’s belongings were locked up for
safety, due to Youth A self-harming. Youth A was provided with
hygiene items when needed, including her hairbrush and
toothbrush.
Analysis Based on interviews with staff and youth, the facility is found to be
in compliance. Although Youth A did not have unlimited access to
her hygiene items, due to safety reasons, staff made them
available as needed.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Ventilation
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4409
Section (1) Except for a basement, each habitable room shall have direct
Description outside ventilation by means of windows, louvers, air conditioning,
or mechanical ventilation.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A was restricted to rooms without sufficient ventilation.
Investigation On 6/26/24 Complainant reported that Youth A was restricted to
a conference room that did not have sufficient air conditioning.
Complainant was at the facility with Youth A from on 6/22/24 from
7:00PM to 10:30PM. During that time the air conditioning was not
working and the rooms were very warm. Complainant stated the
conference room felt like a “hot box”. Complainant reported they
were dripping with sweat. At 10:00PM Youth A was able to
shower before going to bed. Youth A asked for a fan when going
to bed and staff told her she could not have one. On 6/23/24
Complainant arrived at the facility at 7:00AM and found it to be
4

very hot again. Complainant requested and received a fan for
Youth A’s doorway.
On 6/28/24 Youth A was interviewed by MDHHS Worker. Youth A
reported the conference room was hot, due to the air conditioning
not working. However, staff provided a fan in the doorway, but not
in the room due to safety concerns. DCWL attempted to follow up
with Youth A, however she moved from the facility on 6/28/24.
Attempts were made to contact Youth A at her new placement on
8/12/24 and 9/3/24, without success.
On 7/1/24 Supervisor was interviewed on-site at the facility by
Consultant 1 and MDHHS Worker. Supervisor reported Youth A
had ongoing, escalated behavior. Youth A was placed in the
conference room for supervision, as her assaultive and
threatening behaviors on the unit were dangerous to other youth.
Youth A was not locked in the conference room and was only in
there during waking hours, with Complainant supervising her.
Youth A was able to sleep in her own room. Supervisor noted that
the air conditioning was not working well during that time and it
was warm in the building. However, Youth A and Complainant
were provided with a box fan in the conference room.
On 7/1/24 Staff 1 was interviewed on-site at the facility by
Consultant 1 and MDHHS Worker. Staff 1 reported that Youth A
spent time in the conference room as a safety measure. Youth A
had been physically assaulting staff and peers. Staff 1 recalled the
air conditioning was not working well, but a fan was provided to
Youth A.
On 7/1/24 Staff 2 was interviewed by phone by Consultant 1 and
MDHHS worker. Staff 2 acknowledged the building had trouble
with the air conditioning. Staff 2 recalled that a fan was provided to
Youth A.
Consultant 1 was contacted via email on 9/3/24. Consultant 1
reported that while on-site on 7/1/24, they observed fans located
through the sleeping and common areas. Consultant 1 indicated
the building was warm, but not unbearable.
Consultant 3 was contacted via email on 9/3/24. Consultant 3
reported he was on-site at the facility on 8/29/24. The building felt
comfortable in temperature and he did not have any concerns
about the cooling or ventilation.
5

Chief Administrator was contacted via email on 9/3/24. Chief
Administrator reported that two of the five air conditioning units
were malfunctioning beginning May 2024. Because of that, the
facility was not as cool as normal. The units were repaired in July
2024.
Documents reviewed:
• The December 2023 Environmental Health inspection
report was reviewed and found the agency had an A rating.
There were no documented concerns about the facility’s
heating/cooling system.
• A contact by Consultant 1 from 6/5/24 was reviewed. There
were no concerns noted about the temperature of the
facility.
• A 7/1/24 work order from Koch & White Heating and
Cooling was reviewed and found to document air
conditioner repairs as reported by Chief Administrator.
Analysis Based on interviews with youth and staff, and observations on
site, the facility is found to be in compliance. While the agency’s
air conditioning was not working for a time period, the agency
ensured fans were utilized to help circulate air.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules.
